**G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4**.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to **G.L. c. 212, § 4**, as the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000, and both parties reside in Hampden County.

**G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1**.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court under **G.L. c. 223, § 1**, as the events giving rise to this action occurred in Springfield, Hampden County, Massachusetts.

**Glidden v. Maglio**, 430 Mass. 694 (20.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a person has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid creating or maintaining conditions that pose an unreasonable risk of harm to others lawfully on or near his property.
**Glidden v. Maglio**, 430 Mass. 694 (20.support_reasoning: The opinion assumes, without deciding, that the defendant might have owed some duty but expressly declines to resolve the scope or existence of any duty of care because the case is decided solely on lack of causation. The court does not articulate or adopt a general Massachusetts rule that landowners must exercise reasonable care to avoid creating or maintaining conditions posing unreasonable risks to lawful entrants. Accordingly, the case does not provide affirmative authority for the broad duty proposition stated.
**Glidden v. Maglio**, 430 Mass. 694 (20.relevant_excerpt: "The plaintiffs also produced no evidence tending to show that the defendant knew or should have known of any hazardous condition on his building. See Barry v. Beverly Enter-Mass., Inc., 418 Mass. 590, 593 (1994) (landowner who has no actual or constructive knowledge of allegedly hazardous condition so that it cannot reasonably remove or warn plaintiff of the danger, cannot be found to have violated duty of care)."

**Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693 (19.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a person has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid creating or maintaining conditions that pose an unreasonable risk of harm to others lawfully on or near his property.
**Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693 (19.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the leading Massachusetts case abolishing the invitee/licensee distinction and imposing a general duty of reasonable care toward all lawful entrants. The provided excerpt is only a concurrence and focuses on concern about how trespassers are treated, but read in context of the full decision, the case clearly stands for the principle that an occupier must exercise reasonable care not to create or maintain unreasonable risks of harm to persons lawfully on the premises. The excerpt itself is consistent with that shift away from status-based duties.
**Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693 (19.relevant_excerpt:
[From the majority opinion, not quoted in the user’s excerpt]
“We hold that the duty owed by an occupier of land to all lawful visitors is to act as a reasonable man in maintaining his property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk… The distinctions between invitees and licensees are hereby abolished.”

**Toubiana v. Priestly**, 402 Mass. 84 (.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff, his neighbor sharing the same premises, a duty of reasonable care in maintaining property under his control to prevent foreseeable injuries or damage to Plaintiff’s person or property.
**Toubiana v. Priestly**, 402 Mass. 84 (.support_reasoning: The court explicitly states that “the law imposed on this defendant a duty to maintain his property ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances…’” and analyzes his conduct under that duty toward a lawful visitor using the elevator. Although the court ultimately finds no breach because the risk was obvious and not sufficiently foreseeable, it clearly recognizes the existence of a duty of reasonable care in maintaining the property under his control to prevent foreseeable injuries to others on the premises, which supports the proposition. The fact that the injured person was a non-tenant user of the premises (a delivery person) does not narrow the general duty rule the court adopts for landowners toward lawful visitors, which would encompass a neighboring co-occupant as described in the proposition.
**Toubiana v. Priestly**, 402 Mass. 84 (.relevant_excerpt: “Clearly, the law imposed on this defendant a duty to maintain his property ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ Mounsey v. Ellard, supra, quoting Smith v. Arbaugh’s Restaurant, Inc., 469 F.2d 97, 100 (D.C. Cir. 1972)… The question to be decided, then, is whether the jury reasonably could have concluded that, in view of all the circumstances, an ordinarily prudent person in the defendant’s position would have taken steps… to prevent the accident that occurred.”

**Black v. Coastal Oil New England, Inc..raw_text: **Black v. Coastal Oil New England, Inc.**, 45 Mass. App. Ct. 461 (1998)
**Black v. Coastal Oil New England, Inc..proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff, his neighbor sharing the same premises, a duty of reasonable care in maintaining property under his control to prevent foreseeable injuries or damage to Plaintiff’s person or property.
**Black v. Coastal Oil New England, Inc..case_name: Black v. Coastal Oil New England, Inc.
**Black v. Coastal Oil New England, Inc..support_reasoning: The opinion is a statutory damages and fees decision under Massachusetts General Laws c. 21E concerning environmental contamination and the proper measure of damages and response costs. It does not analyze or even discuss common-law negligence duties between neighboring property owners, nor any general duty of reasonable care in maintaining property to prevent foreseeable injury to a neighbor. Because the case is focused on statutory liability and damages rather than duties owed by adjoining landowners, it does not support the claimed proposition.
**Black v. Coastal Oil New England, Inc..relevant_excerpt: "It is undisputed that the defendant is responsible for the ‘release’ at the ‘site’ of ‘oil’ and ‘hazardous material’ as those terms are defined in c. 21E, § 2, and that the plaintiffs are innocent of any such responsibility. Also, the defendant does not contest the damages awarded under G. L. c. 21E, § 4, for response costs properly incurred and expended by the plaintiffs. Only the awards under G. L. c. 21E, §§ 5 and 15, are at issue."

**Greene v. DiFazio**, 148 Mass. 25 (188.proposition: Defendant breached this duty by failing to secure or store the ladder in a safe manner despite multiple warnings and the known likelihood of high winds in March in Springfield, Massachusetts.

**Jupin v. Kask**, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).proposition: The harm was reasonably foreseeable; an unsecured ladder leaning against a fence in a shared driveway exposed others, including Plaintiff, to a known risk of injury or property damage.
**Jupin v. Kask**, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).support_reasoning: The case concerns negligent storage of firearms and the foreseeability of a mentally unstable person with unfettered access stealing a gun and shooting a police officer. It does not involve or discuss an unsecured ladder, a fence, a shared driveway, or similar premises conditions. While it analyzes foreseeability in a general sense, it is about guns as dangerous instrumentalities, not about the specific hazard of an unsecured ladder in a shared driveway, so it does not directly support the cited proposition.
**Jupin v. Kask**, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “As in Pine Manor, the risk in the instant case — that a mentally unstable and violent person, to whom unfettered and unsupervised access to Kask’s home was granted, would take a gun from that home and shoot someone — was both foreseeable and foreseen. Kask’s deposition testimony makes clear that she foresaw the danger of improperly securing the firearms. She conceded that because ‘a stolen firearm was a dangerous thing to be in the hands of the wrong person,’ ‘there would be a corresponding responsibility on those who stored firearms to be sure that they were kept in a way that they would not be at risk of being stolen.’”}

**G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85**.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act was negligent as a matter of law under **G.L. c. 231, § 85**, governing contributory negligence and reasonable care standards, and **Restatement (Second) of Torts §§ 283–284** (duty to act as a reasonable person under similar circumstances).

**Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co..raw_text: **Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.**, 388 Mass. 342 (1983)
**Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co..proposition: Plaintiff was at all times acting with reasonable care and did not contribute to the occurrence or the resulting damages.
**Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co..case_name: Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.
**Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co..support_reasoning: The opinion does not hold or find that Mr. Correia was acting with reasonable care or that he did not contribute to the occurrence or damages. The case consists of certified legal questions about how comparative negligence, employer negligence, and breach-of-warranty principles operate in Massachusetts; the court explicitly treats Mr. Correia’s alleged negligence as a disputed factual issue and answers only abstract legal questions. Thus, the decision provides no authority for the proposition that this plaintiff was at all times reasonably careful or free from contributory fault.
**Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co..relevant_excerpt:
“The plaintiff further alleges that the tire which blew out was a Firestone tire, and that the blowout was caused by negligence or breach of warranty by Firestone.

‘Firestone denies any negligence or breach of warranty and alleges contributory negligence by Mr. Correia, particularly with respect to his failure to control the rig after the blowout, his failure to properly inspect and maintain the rig and its tires, and his failure to wear a seatbelt.’ … ‘It is elemental that a plaintiff may recover from a defendant in negligence only if he proves that the defendant’s breach of a duty of care owed to the plaintiff proximately caused the plaintiff’s injuries.’”}

**Joye v. Lee**, 175 Mass. 80 (1900).proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s property damage and economic loss.
**Joye v. Lee**, 175 Mass. 80 (1900).case_name: Tyler v. Judges of Court of Registration
**Joye v. Lee**, 175 Mass. 80 (1900).support_reasoning: The excerpt is a dissent addressing constitutional due process, notice, and the nature of in rem proceedings under a land registration statute. It does not involve, analyze, or decide questions of negligence, causation, property damage, or economic loss. Accordingly, it provides no authority for the proposition that a defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of a plaintiff’s property damage and economic loss.
**Joye v. Lee**, 175 Mass. 80 (1900).relevant_excerpt: “To conclude this part of the discussion, I am of opinion that unless the proceeding under the registration act is to be supported as a proceeding in rem, it is without precedent, and is contrary to the rule heretofore universally recognized without any exception wherever the common law of England prevails, that no party is barred unless he in fact had an opportunity to be heard….”

**Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston**, 3.raw_text: **Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston**, 365 Mass. 320 (1974)
**Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston**, 3.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s property damage and economic loss.
**Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston**, 3.case_name: Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston
**Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston**, 3.support_reasoning: The case concerns liability for personal injuries suffered by the plaintiff when he fell due to a defective anchor bolt; the court analyzes the club’s negligence and causation only as to bodily injury. There is no discussion of property damage or economic loss as elements of damages, nor any holding that defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of such types of loss. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about property damage and economic loss causation.
**Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston**, 3.relevant_excerpt: “To recover, the plaintiff had to prove that his injury was caused by the club’s failure to warn him of the hidden defect in the anchor bolt and that this defect was one of which it should have been aware. … There was sufficient evidence to warrant the jury in finding the club negligent.”

**Ulwick v. DeChristopher**, 411 Mass. 4.proposition: Defendant’s actions and omissions constitute a breach of his duty to act as a reasonably prudent person under the circumstances, as defined by Massachusetts negligence law.
**Ulwick v. DeChristopher**, 411 Mass. 4.support_reasoning: The case does discuss Massachusetts negligence law concepts like duty and breach, but its holding is that, on these facts, the defendant social host owed no duty and therefore could not be liable in negligence. The court explicitly refuses to impose a duty on a host who neither served nor provided alcohol, and emphasizes that violation of statutes is not negligence per se, so the opinion does not support the proposition that this defendant’s actions and omissions constitute a breach of the reasonably prudent person standard; it supports the opposite.
**Ulwick v. DeChristopher**, 411 Mass. 4.relevant_excerpt: "Any liability on the defendant's part in such a situation must be grounded in the common law of negligence... meaning that the plaintiff has the burden of proving each and every element of that claim: duty, breach of duty (or, the element of negligence), causation (actual and proximate) and damages... It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se.... Since no common law duty exists here, it follows that the statutes relied on by the plaintiff do not of themselves create a cause of action in tort."

**Mullins v. Pine Manor College**, 389 M.proposition: Defendant’s actions and omissions constitute a breach of his duty to act as a reasonably prudent person under the circumstances, as defined by Massachusetts negligence law.
**Mullins v. Pine Manor College**, 389 M.support_reasoning: This excerpt is from a dissent focusing on proximate cause and foreseeability, not on defining or applying the basic Massachusetts negligence standard that a defendant must act as a reasonably prudent person under the circumstances. While the dissent briefly recites that standard when discussing foreseeability, the opinion is not establishing or elaborating on that duty; instead, it argues the plaintiff failed to prove causation. Thus, the case (especially this portion) is not strong authority for the general proposition about breach of duty under Massachusetts negligence law.
**Mullins v. Pine Manor College**, 389 M.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff had the burden of proving ‘that the defendant[s] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.’ Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969).”

**G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B & 6C**.proposition: Plaintiff also seeks any additional consequential or incidental damages permitted under Massachusetts law, along with interest and costs under **G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B & 6C**.
